clinical_study.brief_title: Premixed vs Basal Bolus Insulin Therapy in Older Patients With Type 2 Diabetes
clinical_study.official_title: Is Premixed Insulin Therapy an Alternative to Basal Bolus Therapy in Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus People Older Than 65 Years Old: A Pilot Randomised Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to compare efficacy and security of premixed insulin treatment vs basal bolus insulin treatment in older patients with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes.

primary_outcome.description: Change from baseline in HbA1c levels after 12 months of therapy

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of hypoglycaemia as an adverse effect of the treatment
Incidence of dosing errors as a measure of the safety of the treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Number of dosing errors by month

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the scores of the Diabetes Treatment Satisfaction Questionnaire (DTSQ) from recruitment to month 12.
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to12 months of therapy using the DTSQ questionnaire of satisfactions with the treatment of diabetes.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the scores of the Diabetes Quality Of Life Questionnaire (EsDQOL) from recruitment to month 12.
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to12 months of therapy using the EsDQOL questionnaire of quality of life in diabetic patients

intervention.description: Premixed insulin treatment: 30% of the calculated dose was administered before breakfast and before lunch (biphasic insulin lispro 50% or biphasic insulin aspart 50%) and the remaining 40% of the dose before dinner (biphasic insulin lispro 25% or biphasic insulin aspart insulin 30%).
Basal-bolus insulin treatment: 50% dose in insulin glargine and 50% dose in insulin lispro or aspartic, distributed in equal parts in the 3 main meals

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Outpatients
- Age ≥ 65 years old
- Type 2 diabetes mellitus
- HbA1c ≥9% (74 mmol/mol)
- Previously treated with one or two doses of basal insulin and oral hypoglycaemic agents
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe insulin-resistance
- High doses of corticosteroids
- Chemotherapy treatment
- High comorbidity
- Bad compliance of the treatment
- Frequent severe hypoglycaemia
